Posts.Content: Dec 29, 2011 12:36PM JSwan wrote: Two of my margins after a lumpectomy came back too close.  My surgeon recommended a re-excision, which I had done about a month later.  I was told by my RO that if the margins were still not sufficient after the re-excision they might consider just going with radiation instead of further surgery but it turned out that there was no residual cancer.  I'm glad I had the re-excision (wasn't really considering not doing it) and if it matters, the surgery was a breeze -- no general anesthesia and quick recovery with no pain.
Posts.Title: Margins - Clear (but one is marginally clear) arbouch mawhinney

Posts.Content: Aug 2, 2014 12:16PM JSwan wrote: I have had six breast MRIs (with number seven coming up in October) so I am something of a pro.  From the time I change into the lovely hospital jammies to walking out the door with the complementary water bottle takes roughly an hour but I am only in the machine for about thirty minutes.  I just shut my eyes, zone out and savor being out of contact with the outside world.  The one piece of advice I have is to ask for or bring earplugs because these things are LOUD.  For my first MRI I asked for music through headphones thinking that would be relaxing but I couldn't hear the music over the clanging and the headphones slipped off about five minutes into the procedure anyway. Best of luck on Monday.
Posts.Title: Please describe your breast MRI CeciliaVera Trvler

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2012 02:40PM JSwan wrote: A decision like this is very personal and I can only tell you what my experience and decisions were.  I had a lumpectomy after a year of neoadjuvant anastrozole.  I decided to shoot for a lumpectomy because I wanted to avoid reconstruction and I was told that I would probably need radiation no matter what because of my original tumor size. Even though the MRI prior to surgery showed no remaining disease I ended up with 2.2 cm of residual cancer.  I also had two close margins so I needed a re-excision.  Because I had a lot of tissue removed from a small breast it doesn't look perfect.  But it looks fine in clothes, which is about all you can say for the rest of me anyway.  Actually, it looks perfectly normal in a bra and I have no regrets at all about having the lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy.   Feel free to PM me if you want more details or if I can be of any help.  Best of luck with whatever you decide.
Posts.Title: Seemingly impossible decision CindyT littletower

Posts.Content: May 2, 2011 12:20PM JSwan wrote: pil -- Having responded to your earlier posts I was thinking about you and wondering whether you got your biopsy results.  I don't know anything about papillary carcinoma but if they told you that it usually doesn't spread beyond the breast that is very good news.  This board can be a great source of information and support.  I also recommend "Dr. Susan Love's Breast Book" which is a comprehensive (and thick) book on breast cancer and treatment options.  I found it very helpful and informative.  Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Rare 1% to 2% of women pil rjbaby69

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2011 10:05AM JSwan wrote: pil -- I have invasive lobular cancer and am doing treatment to try and shrink the tumor before surgery.  Seems to be working. My advice to you is to not spend the weekend trying to self-diagnose or compare your symptoms to other's.  Everyone's circumstances are different. Try not to think about all the possibilities and just wait for your biopsy results.  I hope you get them on Monday.  Hang in there.

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2017 04:40PM JSwan wrote: Amanda -- If you want to learn more about gadolinium here is a website devoted to the topic: https://gadoliniumtoxicity.com If you decide to have an MRI, try to find a facility that uses macrocyclic contrast agent instead of a linear agent. Macrocyclic agents are thought to be safer. The European authorities recently recommended that certain linear agents be banned: https://gadoliniumtoxicity.com/2017/03/12/ema-reco... I have had eight breast MRIs (all at AMI in Bozeman, Montana) and seven of them were with linear agents. For my last MRI I asked AMI to use a macrocyclic agent instead and, after much hemming and hawing, they finally agreed. I have been tested (at Mayo) and determined to have elevated levels of gadolinium so my neurologist has recommended that I not have any contrast MRIs unless absolutely necessary. My breast surgeon agrees. I would also suggest that when making your decision you talk to a medical professional who does not have an ownership interest in the MRI machine. MRIs are a huge source of revenue so don't assume that an imaging center or radiologist has only your best interests at heart. I can also tell you that MRIs are not always accurate. After a year of neoadjuvant therapy I had an MRI before surgery that showed no evidence of cancer. In fact, I had 2.2cm of residual disease. As MTwoman said, there are risks and benefits to consider. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Breast MRI Amanda702 Amanda702

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 12:40AM JSwan wrote: I've had two biopsies, one stereotactic and one ultrasound guided.  I am barely a B cup also and there were no problems fitting through the table for the stereotactic biopsy.  I was told to bring my most supportive bra to wear home.  They also told me to keep it on until the next day so you probably do not want it to be your most uncomfortable one. I would not recommend going to work afterward just because you will be sore and cranky (at least I was -- plus I was sent home in a pressure bandage to control the bleeding) and you will be told to ice it throughout the day, which may be difficult in a work setting.  Another tip -- tell them to give you plenty of lidocaine and to wait for it to take effect before proceeding.  The doctor who did my sterotactic biopsy gave me one shot of lidocaine and started with the procedure within 30 seconds.  The pain was unbeliveable.  The doctor who did my second biopsy gave me several shots and waited awhile before proceeding.  No pain at all.  Best of luck with your biopsy.  Here's hoping you will have an easy time of it and will get good results.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic tips, anyone? jadeblue jadeblue

Posts.Content: Dec 28, 2011 05:16AM JSwan wrote: Spinnerpom -- I am Scandinavian and very fair skinned.  I am on my last week of 33 rads and have had no problems at all beyond a little redness on my collarbone.  I wish you the same.
Posts.Title: "Easy" part of treatment? MY A**! BlueCowgirl Tazzy

Posts.Content: May 11, 2011 09:08AM - edited May 11, 2011 09:30AM by JSwan I was on HRT for two years before being diagnosed.  They told me that the HRT didn't cause my breast cancer, which probably had been there for years, but certainly fueled it.  My tumor had actually been palpable for years but they kept me on the HRT because my mammograms came back clear.  It wasn't until I insisted on an ultrasound that my cancer was diagnosed.  I'm on anastrozole now.
